I love chewing gum; I have perfect teeth that people comment on all the time. And, my dentist gives out Spry gum with xylitol. I think it's a great idea. Learning about chewing gum in Kindergarten can also help children learn responsible disposal and may help the kids who are anxious or have a hard time focusing--a terrific but unintended consequence. Why all the hate for gum?

A great column, as always, Professor Krugman.

So much of the focus of the discussion about the supposed "fiscal cliff" (which isn't one) has been about tax rates and "revenues," but there's been very little focus on which taxes and which rates.

The capital gains, carried interest, estate tax, and hedge fund managers' giveaways to the rich are among the worst offenders we have in the huge income and wealth gap we face in this country.

What's also clear is that so many in the media are now part of the 1% and work for the plutocracy that they cannot or will not spell out what's really at stake. This paper failed again and again to discuss Romney's record at Bain, or to lay out clearly and directly what his tax and budget plans were. Why?

But a majority saw through the fog, and agree with the president that the rich must pay more. 91% seems a bit high for today, but the Clinton-era rates--on all kinds of income, not just federal marginal tax rates--seem a reasonable start. Let's make sure the GOP and billionaires don't get their way, and that the Democrats and our President don't cave.

That's not what we voted for.

Google "power inlet box" for a way you can get around the need to run an extension cord through a partly opened window or door to your natural gas heating system.  Then you can plug your generator into this special electrical "inlet" installed on the outside of your house that can then be wired or connected from inside to your gas heater.

Being in Sunny So CA, I opted for a cheap solution.  Bought a 4000W portable gasoline generator for less than $300 from Harbor Freight Tools.  I'll have the hassle of "stabilizing"/rotating out my 5 gals of gasoline with Stabil once per year, but far cheaper than the thousands of dollars other solutions would run for me.  I have the ability to run the fridge and some power tools.  I don't have a/c anyways.  I suppose I could run an extension cord to the heater (if I have nat gas flowing) to run the heater if it is winter.  My power is out perhaps 2 hrs/yr, so the generator is unnecessary for "normal" outages.  My system is strictly for "big" emergencies, such as an earthquake...

The one thing that worries me about comparisons of now versus the 1950s is that in the 1950s the rest of the world had been bombed flat and/or economically emasculated by totalitarian communism.  America had no economic competitors to speak of in the 1950s and a world hungry for American goods that people couldn't create or build themselves.  As much as I agree with you, those (hopefully never to be repeated) conditions had to be important contributors to American prosperity from 1947-73, but I never hear any estimates of how much they contributed to our rising prosperity.

It is conventional wisdom but an economic fallacy that globalization has created an impediment to 1950s prosperity.  If low wage countries want to make goods and ship them to the US, then that frees up our workers to make more advanced products, infrastructure, housing, etc.  And if we have too many workers, maybe we should shorten to work week.  In the 1960s I was told that a 4 day work week was in the not to distant future, but since then we have gone in the opposite direction.  The real issues, as Prof. Krugman pointed out, are inequitable distribution of earnings and concentration of wealth.

Paul, there's no question that the current craze for lower marginal rates is completely misguided.

What we've learned since the early 1980s is that lowering marginal rates on wealthy individuals has absolutely no impact on whether good paying jobs remain in America or get shipped overseas - no impact at all.

This nation urgently needs to respond to the challenges of globalism - and find ways of making American labor more competitive in a global marketplace.

We need policies that offer a chance of returning as many high-value manufacturing and service jobs to America as can be.

We gave supply-side economics thirty-plus years to prove its value to the nation It couldn't.

It's now time to try something completely different - not more of the same old snake oil.

For those who were around when this card was launched, there were people buying just enough of them to be able to keep swiping others continuously in for a sligtly smaller fee than one ride and making a profit. The mta went after those people at the time.
The ethicist should definitely take his job more seriously. I did not care much for his predecesssor, but he at least checked the facts before writing the column.

On a trip to NYC a MTA employee told my husband and me that it was all right to purchase one card for two people and hand it back over the turnstile. While he was clearly wrong according to your reference, I would have been furious if I had been punished in any way for following the advice of the MTA man at Kennedy airport's air/train terminal.
People swipe when they are leaving the station, not going into the station, so their trip has been completed and they are in compliance.

The Ethicist answer on the Metrocard question is completely wrong. The MTA's terms of use for the Metrocard say that the card "cannot be used by or transferred to another person until the completion of a trip for which entry was obtained." (see http://www.mta.info/metrocard/termsunltd.htm). Swiping for someone else's trip is thus violating the subway's rules and may be treated by the law similar to farebeating (i.e. fine and possible jail time). The MTA has said elsewhere that giving or lending your Metrocard to someone else is OK, as long as the card stays with them for the entire transit trip.

I respectfully suggest that the Ethicist has an ethical obligation to do his homework before recommending lawbreaking behavior in his column.

This system collapsed in 2008. We've simply been borrowing $1 trillion per year to prop it up and printing a lot of money (the Fed's balance sheet has expanded from $800B to almost $3 trillion).

The crisis in 2008 represented the private sector cutting off our 20-year borrowing-based consumption binge. The ratio of household debt relative to disposable income rose from about 80% in 1990 to 130% by 2007, when the House of Cards came down.

Fixing this mess means:

1) Bringing the jobs home to eliminate our trade deficit;
2) Raising taxes significantly on the wealthy;
3) Addressing the drivers of healthcare costs;
4) Shifting from defense spending to infrastructure, green energy and education;
5) Giving labor a seat on the board, as they do in Germany, and separating CEO and Chairman roles;
6) Public funding of federal campaigns; and
7) Term limits.

Instead, we are talking about raising taxes on the top 2% back to Clinton levels and continuing the freeze on federal spending (in place since 2009, at around $3.5 trillion).

Interesting game, in that despite the ultimately easy victory, in the first half --- everything (save the starting QB issues) that has epitomized the Jets' problems so far... happened to them. It started with another awful drop by Hill that crushed the momentum of the first drive -- with the next play nearly resulting in a turnover. Then, the continued misuse of Tebow: putting him in after 2 long runs got the ball to midfield, only to lose a yard on a totally disorganized play call. Then you had the special teams gaffes: the blocked field goal and the botched fake punt (which Dan Fouts pinned on Tebow, for not recognizing the Rams had their regular defense in). So they overcame all that and played well and won.
But it just seems too little too late.
In the game preview thread below, Walt mentioned how losing to Miami hurt the Jets playoff chances. But it was really the overtime loss to New England that drastically altered the calculus of the season. Win that, you're essentially playing for the division lead Thursday. Now, it's pretty much a must-win to keep their Wild Card hopes on life support. Can they eliminate the above mistakes and beat the Patriots? I don't see it happening. I hope I'm wrong.

Why is it so common for sports writers to feel it necessary to overstate and falsify their comparisons to make a point? It is certainly true that thus far the Knicks have received good production from their THREE point guards combined, but why would you put their combined statistics (48 minutes' worth, I assume) against Lin's single set? Are you claiming that he plays 48 minutes? Really?

As has also been pointed out, he is playing on a young team who don't even have their coach (!). What a silly statistical comparison at the wrong time. What a sensational piece of blather. Why are you distracting from your own central point--that the Knicks are going to have to prove that they're durable at their age--with a thin argument after a few weeks of a young season?

I'm glad to have Felton back--always liked him--but I wish we'd never traded him. Any Knicks fan will hope that his best years are now--although if you look back at the Times archive, you'll find plenty to argue that that is a long-shot bet. I'm hopeful for Prigioni, but I DO remember last year when Lin BLEW past an aging, tired Kidd. And Lin is just LEARNING the game.

Statistics after 7 games are so meaningless and non-predictive. Any decent sports WATCHER knows that. Shouldn't a professional be even MORE aware? S'pose not.

The Yacht Index (noting references to boats as a wealth tracker)

Recently a yacht broker in the Hamptons who has experience going back to the 1970's told me that the volume of sales of sailing "yachts" (not windsurfing, kitesurfing, Olympic-class boats, Hobies etc., but sailboats fitted out for coastal sailing, ocean racing, family cruising) has been diminishing since the '80s.

There is a production scale boat industry. In California and the East Coast companies such as Pearson and Cal were busy from the '60s to the '80s putting out sailboats for the U.S. middle class. Perhaps interest in sailing itself changed, but it is true that a market that might be described as luxury for middle class has diminished.

A number of commentators have pointed out how American manufacturing had a distinct advantage in the 1950s, since our factories were not decimated by World War II.  We can't go back to that time, but we can work toward leveling the playing field with more than simply increased taxes on the wealthy.  We can also start talking about a tariff on imported goods produced in countries that don't pay their people anything approximating an American minimum wage.  And how about environmental tariffs on those countries that exempt themselves from anything close to U.S. laws on pollution?  The money from these tariffs could help a lot of Americans in need and take some of the steam out of those who want to destroy our safety net in order to balance the budget.

phillygirl: In the 1950's, you would have been hired as a legal secretary, not an attorney, despite a law degree and excelling in your class. See Sandra Day O'Connor. Other than that, agree with your points on appalling values.

Historical footnote: In the 1960s, when I was a Harvard undergraduate, the Business School was looked down on. A friend and I, it turned out, had had a date or two with the same guy, whom we identified as a student at HBS. We dubbed him "B-School John", and sneered whenever his name came up. We all wanted to marry professors (doctors and lawyers were okay, too), and the more enlightened of us also wanted to be professors (or doctors or lawyers).

There's another big plus in leveling income distribution, and that has to do with the distribution of talent. Among graduates of elite schools, gobsmacking numbers head for Wall Street, the most swollen and useless sector of the economy, while in the 50's this human capital went into teaching, science, engineering and other productive pursuits.

As a lawyer, I'd love to be transported to the 50's and 60's, when the federal government and white-shoe law firms started new lawyers at roughly the same salary. In my law school class, not even that recent, most of the people who started with a commitment to good government and social justice (how quaint) ended up at Manhattan megafirms, designing tax-avoidance and labor-crushing strategies for five times what they'd make in government or nonprofit jobs. Gotta repay all that student-loan debt, of course. Any society pays for what it values, and our values are appalling. Not sure how much you can correct this with tax policy, but it's worth trying.

Important reading for the people who are screaming at the tops of their lungs that State Dept security was inadequate, and who are claiming some sort of cover-up by the Obama administration. To use an over-used word, the practice of diplomacy is much more "nuanced" than many would have you believe.

With all the terrorists and mad bombers on the loose these days, it is difficult to concoct policies that work well in our various diplomatic posts throughout the world. It's almost as though we need to sneak in a bunch of CIA operatives to find out undercover what's really going on, then to distill their findings for the benefit of the diplomats who stay behind the moat, except when it is necessary to pay official visits to foreign government functionaries.

Our nation has been divided before and saved before.
We are in the midst of an enormous crisis of wealth, one that has gotten worse decade by decade.
At the same time, a large class of very savvy people now understand that we stand at a crossroads.
We can move to close the wealth gap or we can allow our country to be hopelessly divided by wealth.
This is a crisis, and we need to not be diverted by the daily onslaught of irrelevant "breaking news".
President Obama and congress need to know that we will not tolerate anything short of real and substantial compromise on the part of Republicans.

As a seventeen year old who is often labeled a hipster, I found this very fascinating. It makes me question myself quite a bit... do I like hipster things because I like them or because they are hispter? Was there an original hipster subculture that happened to have certain qualities, and then, once others caught on to their intriguing irony, they just conformed to said qualities? Is liking coffee and Ray Ban sunglasses and British television just a result of some subconscious desire to appear ironic in the eyes of society? Or do I in fact like coffee and Ray Ban sunglasses and British television? And will I ever be able to tell? Does it even matter?

I figure that all those exotic financial instruments that the Wizards of Wall Street are creating are the modern equivalent to when the banks printed their own currencies in the 19th century.  We know how well that turned out.  You get a piece of paper, ie. derivative, that can't be converted to tangible assets with inherent value.  Somebody ends up holding the bag when it all comes crashing down.  Cash in greenbacks could probably be considered a first derivative.  Securitized mortgages are probably something like a 5th derivative that bear little relation to the real value of a home.
I like Paul Volcker's comment: the last financial innovation that improved our lives was the ATM.

The lower tax scheme has the unique distinction of being both a red herring and the elephant in the room. It is supposed to distract the voter from the fact that the reasons the econmy is faltering lays in the shift from a production based industry to a financial and trade industry based on transactions and comissions and bonuses. Since that getting rich scheme essentially means taking from others - because nothing actually is produced, just evaluated differently - it has to pretend it is necessary and useful to the whole of the nation. Which better way to do that, than to annoite oneself (i.e. the investment class) as the most essential of organs in the economic body and to claim organ failure to lead to death.

The elephant in the room is the fact, that these Republican law-breakers in Congress really are schoolyard bullies of the worst kind. Imbecellic. Incapable. Immoral.
